display_asset.caption: People surf on the wave of a tidal bore known as “Pororoca” in March 2015 during an annual festival in Sao Domingos do Capim, Brazil.

summaries.body: This week surfers will ride a wave in the Amazon. The Pororoca, a tidal bore, tumbles in from the ocean and up the river on a path of destruction. But surfers love it.

display_asset.caption: Arnold Demoski, 26, of Nulato, Alaska, who was charged with driving a snowmobile into two teams of Iditarod dog-sled racers on Saturday.

summaries.body: A snowmobile driver who was accused of colliding with mushers in the Iditarod dog-sled race in Alaska has apologized, saying that he had been drinking. One dog was killed.

display_asset.caption: Passengers huddled near an Amtrak train that derailed in southwest Kansas early Monday.

summaries.body: An Amtrak passenger train on its way to Chicago from Los Angeles came off the tracks in Kansas, sending more than 30 people to hospitals.

display_asset.caption: A rocket carrying the ExoMars 2016 spacecraft took off from the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan on Monday.

summaries.body: The ExoMars 2016 mission blasted off from Kazakhstan on Monday. The spacecraft's orbiter will measure gases in the Martian atmosphere. A lander will study dust storms.

display_asset.caption: President Xi Jinping at the opening session of the Chinese People’s Political Consultative Conference in Beijing.

summaries.body: President Xi Jinping was brought down a notch by a typo in a Xinhua article that called him “China’s last leader,” not “China’s highest.”

posts.footer: The New York Review of Books

summaries.body: A new film from one of Thailand’s most respected directors uses a fantastical conceit — telling the story of soldiers trapped in an inescapable sleep — to construct an allegory for the country’s political situation.

display_asset.caption: The South Korean professional Go player Lee Se-dol, center, reviewing the match with other experts after the fourth match against Google’s artificial intelligence program, AlphaGo, on Sunday.

summaries.body: After three straight losses, the master Go player Lee Se-dol rallied for his first victory against a Google program playing the ancient board game.

display_asset.caption: Pablo Picasso’s “Bust of a Woman” (1931) was on display at the Museum of Modern Art as part of the exhibition “Picasso Sculpture.”
display_asset.credit: 2015 Estate of Pablo Picasso/Artists Rights Society (ARS), New York, Philip Greenberg for The New York Times

summaries.body: The battle over a rare Picasso bust intensified with new legal complaints that the artist's daughter canceled a sale of the work and tried to secretly close a better deal.
The short battery life of electric cars can be frustrating for drivers. A father-daughter design team has come up with a solution: roads that recharge the cars as they drive.
Researchers are exploring the limits of friction as they design tiny robots that can pull thousands of times their weight and wander like lizards on vertical surfaces.

display_asset.caption: Women dancing late at night near a residential compound in Beijing.

summaries.body: For the “dancing grannies” who crowd public spaces across China, nothing will stop the music, not even gunfire.
The hit play "War Horse" is on its final gallop in Britain, but its legacy lives on in a changed National Theater and industry.

display_asset.caption: Sunrise at Cape Porpoise Harbor in Kennebunkport, Me. Some anti-federalists are opposed to daylight saving time, considering it unnecessary government intervention.

summaries.body: Do we really need daylight saving time? We’re springing forward again. But why? Let The Times explain this widely misunderstood ritual.
Immaturity may be mistaken for A.D.H.D., according to a study showing that the youngest students in a classroom are more likely to be given a diagnosis of A.D.H.D.

display_asset.caption: A view of the sun during the spring eclipse season from the Solar Dynamic Observatory.

summaries.body: We saw a solar eclipse this week, but NASA’s Solar Dynamics Observatory, 22,000 miles in space, watched Earth cross the sun every day for nearly a month.
Lanvin has named Bouchra Jarrar artistic director of women’s collections, putting a woman once again at the helm of the oldest continuous couture house in Paris.

display_asset.caption: A scene from a Dos Equis ad featuring Jonathan Goldsmith as “the Most Interesting Man in the World.”

summaries.body: They are part of our lives, ubiquitously appearing in 30-second blasts. Then the pitchmen just disappear. And with the retirement of the Most Interesting Man in the World, The Times presents a look at other bygone barkers.

display_asset.caption: Women dancing late at night near a residential compound in Beijing.

summaries.body: Friction between "dancing grannies" — elderly outdoor dance enthusiasts in China — and residents grew serious as a woman was hurt by an air rifle, according to news reports.

display_asset.caption: Jeff Probst, the host of “Survivor” and an executive producer, said that the temperature was well over 100 degrees on the day the episode was shot last spring, but that having three contestants collapse was unprecedented.

summaries.body: Three contestants collapsed and one was rushed to the hospital on "Survivor" this week. “This won’t be the last evacuation,” the show's host said of the grueling season.
Physicians and lawyers top the list of highest paid professions in the United States this year, according to data compiled by Glassdoor, a jobs website.

display_asset.caption: Boris Weisfeiler, who disappeared in Chile in 1985.
display_asset.credit: Wendy Maeda/The Boston Globe, via Getty Images

summaries.body: A judge closed a case against retired police and military officers accused of abducting an American who vanished in Chile 31 years ago, a mystery that may never be solved.
A child who was found in a carry-on bag on an Air France flight this week is in the care of French authorities.

display_asset.caption: Constance Malcolm, center, in black shirt, at a rally on Thursday at City Hall organized to demand justice in the 2012 killing of her son, Ramarley Graham, who was 18 when he was fatally shot in his Bronx apartment by Police Officer Richard Haste.

summaries.body: A white New York City police officer who fatally shot Ramarley Graham, an unarmed black teenager, in his home in the Bronx faces an internal Police Department investigation.

display_asset.caption: Steven Leslie in front of the casket of former first lady Nancy Reagan at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library in Simi Valley, Calif. on Wednesday.
display_asset.credit: Wally Skalij/Los Angeles Times, via Associated Press

summaries.body: Several thousand people traveled to the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library to pay respects to Nancy Reagan and to celebrate the couple's enduring romance.

display_asset.caption: One of six meteorites recovered by a team of amateur meteorite hunters from a fireball that flew over Florida on Jan. 24.

summaries.body: Using data on the American Meteor Society website, amateur scientists have been having remarkable success tracking down meteor pieces that have plunged to earth.

display_asset.caption: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, whose writings will be the subject of a book coming out in January.
display_asset.credit: Charlie Mahoney for The New York Times

summaries.body: A collection of Ruth Bader Ginsburg’s writings and speeches will be published next year, addressing subjects like Jewish identity, gender equality and the Constitution.
Tall men are paid more, and overweight women are paid less, according to a new study on the cause-and-effect relationship between physical characteristics and pay.

display_asset.caption: Brandon Sherrod and his Yale teammates celebrated their Ivy League title with a win over Columbia last week. Next year, a similar performance will earn a No. 1 seed in the league’s postseason tournament.

summaries.body: As the lone holdout in Division I, the Ivy League announced that next year it will begin holding men's and women's postseason basketball tournaments.

display_asset.caption: Nadya V. Savchenko delivered her final statement to the court in the southern Russian town of Donetsk, on Wednesday.

summaries.body: A Ukrainian military pilot being held in Moscow ended a hunger strike by drinking water, her lawyer said, adding that she may have been tricked by Russian intelligence agents.

A lawsuit accuses the dean of the University of California, Berkeley, law school of sexually harassing his executive assistant, and it says the school didn't take appropriate action after an investigation found her claims justified.
